docs.lead_paragraph: Efforts to maintain uninterrupted services to the 194,000 customers of the financially troubled H.I.P. Health Plan of New Jersey hit a new roadblock today when the company providing medical services to the plan's members sought to liquidate itself in bankruptcy court. The medical management company, Pinnacle Healthcare Enterprises, moved in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., to convert its week-old Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing -- in which it had sought to reorganize itself -- into a Chapter 7 filing, under which it could sell off its assets to satisfy creditors. If granted, the move could pave the way for the sale of the 23 health centers where H.I.P.'s members now receive their primary health care.

headline.main: Latest Bankruptcy Filing Threatens Services at H.M.O.

docs.abstract: Efforts to maintain uninterrupted services to 194,000 customers of financially troubled HIP Health Plan of New Jersey hits new roadblock when Pinnacle Healthcare Enterprises, company providing medical services to plan's members, seeks to liquidate itself in bankruptcy court (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Callers to the message line of the Federal Express pilots' union just last Thursday were reassured that the pilots had Fedex on the run. ''We are pulling together to fight for our families and our careers,'' Byron Cobb, the union's vice president, said in the message. ''The plan is working.''

headline.main: How Fedex Made Its Pilots Blink; Culture Colored by Chairman's Resolve Overwhelms Union

docs.abstract: Federal Express Co's pilot called off their threatened holiday strike because they were worried that company's founder Fred Smith would keep shipments going without them by spending tens of millions of dollars to contract out flights; graph; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Members of the American Public Health Association -- some 14,000 doctors, nurses, educators and administrators in the nation's largest group of public health-care workers -- convened in Washington last week to answer two questions: Has managed care given the country the health care it needs at a price it can afford? And if not, can it be fixed? The delegates answered the first question with a resounding no. But the answer to the second was far more complicated.

headline.main: Public Health Group Debates Managed Care

docs.lead_paragraph: FOUR little wooden houses on 92d and 93d Street in Carnegie Hill are signature elements of the neighborhood, like the brownstones of Brooklyn Heights or the Tudor houses of Riverdale. Three of the houses are between Park and Lexington Avenues, the fourth between Lexington and Third. And as the new owners of one of the three off Park, the 1871 clapboard house at 120 East 92d, finish a renovation, they are hoping someone will undertake an even larger task -- moving the fourth house diagonally across Lexington and onto their block. The Yorkville area developed to village proportions in the mid-19th century, reinforced by the East 86th Street ferry to Astoria, the Third Avenue railroad and the industries that sprang up along the upper part of the East River. In 1859 Adam Flanagan, a Custom House officer, built the Italianate-style wooden house at 122 East 92d Street. Twelve years later Catherine Rennert, wife of John C. Rennert, a California wine importer, built the wooden house at No. 120. The Rennerts lived in a wooden house at 114 East 92d, now demolished.

headline.main: Streetscapes / 92d and 93d Street Between Park and Third Avenue; 4 Wooden Houses With a Mid-19th-Century Feel

docs.lead_paragraph: ONCE upon a time, and not too long ago a time, St. Francis Hospital in Hartford was a prototype of the Catholic hospital of the Northeast -- somber and quiet, with paintings of saints here and there, and sisters in black habits passing silently through the corridors. But it has changed, dramatically. Today, the institution might accurately be described as a Pygmalion of hospitals. A visitor or patient who remembers it from a decade ago would be hard pressed to recognize it now.

headline.main: The View From/St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center, Hartford; How Art, and an Artist, Join in the Healing Process

docs.abstract: Article describes dramatic changes at St Francis Hospital in Hartford, Conn, which, over past decade, has become largest Catholic hospital in New England; complex has become less staid and more bright and cheerful; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S alive! The savings and loan debacle, which has cost taxpayers $165 billion, is about to become more expensive. That may come as a surprise to those who thought the costliest bailout in American history was long completed, as much a ghost of the 80's as Rubik's cubes, break dancing or perestroika.

headline.main: The Debacle That Buried Washington; Long After the S.& L. Crisis, Courts Are Handing Taxpayers a New Bill

docs.abstract: US Court of Federal Claims Chief Judge Loren A Smith is about to assess damages in first big test case stemming from 1980's savings and loan crisis; size of award to Glendale Federal Bank, California savings and loan that nearly collapsed, could set tone for other settlements and may cost taxpayers anywhere from $4 billion to $50 billion; photos (M)
